channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Tortuous History Traced in Sunken Slave Ship Found Off South Africa
item.description: The Smithsonian will announce Tuesday that the wreckage of a vessel that sank in 1794 has been found, the first time a slaving ship that went down with slaves aboard has been recovered.
item.category: National Museum of African American History and Culture
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: Western Officials Alarmed as Islamic State Expands Territory in Libya
item.description: The group’s expansion in Libya gives it an alternative base of operations as it appears to be gaining ground in Palmyra in Syria and in Ramadi in Iraq.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SULIMAN ALI ZWAY and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Secretary of State John Kerry Cuts Europe Trip Short After Bike Crash
item.description: Mr. Kerry suffered a broken leg while bicycling in France and was returning to Boston for treatment.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry had been scheduled to fly to Madrid this afternoon for an official visit, then travel to Paris for a meeting on Tuesday.

item.title: China Says It Could Set Up Air Defense Zone in South China Sea
item.description: A Chinese admiral told a security forum in Singapore that Beijing could create a zone above disputed areas if it felt it was facing a large enough threat.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: U.S. Paid Residents Linked to Nazi Crimes $20 Million in Benefits, Report Says
item.description: A report by the Social Security Administration’s inspector general concludes that virtually all of the payments were proper under policies in place at the time.
item.dc:creator: ERIC LICHTBLAU

item.title: Russia’s Barring of Officials Seen as Reprisal
item.description: The European Union confirmed the existence of a list of officials that Russia has barred, a move thought to be retaliation for the group’s barring of Russians said to have backed the annexation of Crimea.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Ex-President of Georgia to Lead Ukraine Region
item.description: President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine appointed Mikheil Saakashvili as governor of Odessa, turning to a longtime nemesis of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia for help governing an area coveted by pro-Russian separatists.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Malaysians Seek Escape in Pulp Fiction as Government’s Grip Tightens
item.description: A new-style pulp fiction in Malaysia has tapped into a desire for escapism among younger Malaysians as their country has become more socially conservative.
item.dc:creator: CHEN MAY YEE
item.media:credit: Rahman Roslan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wani Ardy, left, proprietor of a “pop up” book market, with Amir Muhammad, founder of a publishing company.

item.title: Syrian Army Airstrikes Kill at Least 70 People in Aleppo
item.description: The attacks occurred in two separate instances when government helicopters dropped explosives-filled barrels, activists said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Building of Islands Is Debated, but China and U.S. Skirt Conflict at Talks
item.description: After a week of public rancor over China’s rush to build artificial islands on reefs, rocks and atolls in the disputed waters of the South China Sea, an annual security meeting in Singapore presented a chance to lower the temperature.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Adm. Sun Jianguo of China, left, and Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter at the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore on Saturday. American officials made it clear that disputes in the South China Sea would not hinder nascent military cooperation with China.

item.title: Hundreds Protest After Gunmen Target Ethnic Pashtuns in Southern Pakistan
item.description: Hundreds of demonstrators are demanding punishment for the unidentified killers who attacked two buses and fatally shot at least 22 ethnic Pashtuns.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD and ZIA ur-REHMAN
item.media:description: Pakistani volunteers tried to identify the bodies of some of the 22 people killed Friday night in attacks in Baluchistan.

item.title: Ukrainian Migrants Fleeing Conflict Get a Cool Reception in Europe
item.description: Favored destinations in the European Union for Ukrainian asylum-seekers have overwhelmingly rejected their applications, saying that unlike other restive nations, areas of Ukraine remain secure.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volodymyr Zelenyuk, 28, works at Ukrainian World. He and his wife fled their country, seeking asylum in Poland, where there are now an estimated 400,000 Ukrainians.

item.title: In France, a Party’s Name Change Tracks a Drift to the Right in Europe
item.description: In adopting a name that plays to French nationalism, the party led by former President Nicolas Sarkozy is offering the latest evidence of the ways in which the far-right National Front is reshaping politics.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Nicolas Sarkozy, a former president of France and the leader of the party that has been renamed the Republicans, spoke at a rally in Paris on Saturday.

item.title: Thousands Rescued Off Libya in 22 Operations in One Day
item.description: Italian officials demanded that its European partners help more with the migrants, who have been coming in huge numbers this year. Last year, Italy rescued some 170,000 migrants at sea.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Afghan Police Chief, Long a Taliban Target, Faces a New Emotion: Fear
item.description: With Afghan politics shifting, Gen. Abdul Raziq believes his main accomplishment, making Kandahar Province relatively peaceful amid Taliban territory, is no longer enough to protect him.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gen. Abdul Raziq, the police chief of Kandahar Province, shadowed at home by one of his many bodyguards. He has made the province relatively peaceful but has been accused of abuses.

item.title: Opinion: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie: My Father’s Kidnapping
item.description: My 83-year-old dad was held for ransom. He’ll never forget it.
item.dc:creator: CHIMAMANDA NGOZI ADICHIE

item.title: Sepp Blatter Blames U.S. and England for FIFA Arrests
item.description: The recently re-elected president of FIFA struck a defiant tone as he responded to allegations of widespread corruption in international soccer.
item.dc:creator: JERÉ LONGMAN
item.media:description: Sepp Blatter spoke to reporters on Saturday and said the recent arrests stemmed from resentment by England and the United States.

item.title: Talks Begin to Conclude Nuclear Deal With Iran
item.description: With only a month to go before a deadline for finalizing a nuclear accord with Iran, Secretary of State John Kerry began a major push Saturday to conclude the agreement.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: How the Cayman Islands Became a FIFA Power
item.description: Under FIFA’s system, the smallest country has the same voting power as the biggest, and payments from FIFA for projects help to ensure allegiance to Sepp Blatter.
item.dc:creator: JERÉ LONGMAN
item.media:credit: Angel Valentin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Local soccer players in the Annex, a sports facility in George Town, on Grand Cayman Island.

item.title: Mohamed Soltan, U.S. Citizen Imprisoned in Egypt, Is Released
item.description: Mr. Soltan, who was arrested during the protests over the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi, gained attention through letters smuggled out of prison.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Mohammed Soltan is pushed by his father during a court appearance in Cairo on March 9.
